It was so great to have you here at the Incredible Science Machine!! You brought so much energy to the team! Thanks for highlighting our event and doing this study - it was super fascinating to watch :)

This is exactly what I would have predicted: the bottom of the domino slips backwards more on surfaces with less friction and the domino line topples faster. I did my AP physics project on a similar concept and found that a smaller spacing on sandpaper (frictional surface) was SLOWER than a large spacing on sandpaper. What's interesting is that my original hypothesis was the exact opposite. From experience, usually a larger spacing is slightly slower on a normal wooden floor, but I didn't account for the floor surface when I made my hypothesis. A slippery floor surface (and also domino material, hence the color to speed variation) such as glass makes the dominoes fall faster.

You're right though that this is more complicated than we think, and having an unexplored area of domino physics is super exciting :) Can't wait to see what you discover in the next experiment!

Also a suggestion for starting the dominoes... I feel like we need some sort of motorized toppler that very, very slowly moves forward hitting the center of the first domino near the top. If you use a small spacing, the first domino may just lean against the next domino and not topple right away, but this would allow the bare minimum force required to topple the line. You're also right that a longer line is necessary so that the speed of the dominoes can reach terminal velocity. I'm not 100% sure how many dominoes that is (this could also vary with spacing), but I'd recommend maybe 50 in the line to be safe. Thanks again for coming! And now to watch the behind the scenes :D

If the dominos are on a grippy surface, the moment of inertia is ML^2/3, if it is rotating about its center it is ML^2/12, roughly. So the center of masses fall the same height regardless so the PE->KE has the PE per block as the same value, whereas the KE=1/2*I*w^2, so for a domino that rotates about its center of mass would expect omega to be greater at any point in time, making the domino contact the next one quicker.

The overall picture is certainly more complicated, but this would be the simplest explanation that pops into my mind.

My sons and I have been building dominoes for over a year now (inspired by people like Hevesh5 and Flippycat). Check out our channel (Room 4 Domino)! We have hard wood floors, and it was very challenging to do some tricks at the beginning, so we searched for different alternatives for a surface for our setups. We found that in general more friction is better, some tricks just never worked in the hard and smooth surface. Then the dominoes bounce on the wood, and that combined with the slipping meant that things would be toppled unexpectedly. So surfaces like cork help cushion the fall and stop them from sliding away too far, they fall more neatly. I'd love to see a longer line filmed by your high speed camera, of say 100 dominoes, and compare the falling speed of dominoes of different materials and colours. I wonder if the clear dominoes actually weigh more, maybe it was just the two dominoes you weighed. I'd try weighing 100 and see if there's a statistical difference between the two groups. Also a way of starting the domino line consistently could be a pendulum with a constant weight, length and angle. That should give you a more consistent force.

An easy way to get a consistent starting force would be to use a servo or stepper motor and basic microcontroller (i.e. Arduino). Depending on how geeky you want to get you can use the same signal to trigger the domino starter and the camera. You could also vary how high up on the initial domino you hit to see if that has any effect.

You could build a simple device with a spring, where you would compress the spring and then release it. Doing so, you can set up the same initial conditions (in this case, velocity condition) for all sets of dominoes to the experiment.
Another way, it would be to build a device to hold the first of the dominoes in an angled position and then release it, in this way, making a displacement initial condition.
Another thing I think you have to consider is that the impact of each domino at the same time dissipates energy and acts like a source on the next one.
To summarize, this problem is actually more complicated than it seems to be.

Destin, this really interested me. I was intrigued how the dominoes that slip at the bottom are actually falling faster. I had a moment where I thought of it like how I shoot a hockey puck. The rate of the acceleration of the stack of falling dominoes has to do with two things. 1. The friction of the surface, because of, 2. The rotational inertia of the falling domino.

A falling domino, acting if it were a hinged door falling on its side, has a higher rotational inertia than a domino spinning about its center of mass. A domino who's lower friction can accelerate fast enough to overcome the friction between itself and the surface on which it resides will "give up" rotating like a hinge, and instead favor rotation about its CG.

Each contact of the previously fallen domino exerts an impulse on the next domino, accelerating it foward. At this point its a race. Will the fall of the domino cause it to loose friction, drop inertia and thus accelerate (like kids on a merry go round pulling inward)? Or, the domino fall as if it were hinged on the surface. The former travels through a stack of dominoes faster than the latter.

Which domino falls faster probably has less to do with weight and more to do with static, kinetic, and the coefficient of friction along with transfer of energy from one domino to the next.
i.e.: More slippage = less friction -> less energy lost due to friction -> more energy to convert from potential to kinetic energy -> more energy transferred to the next domino = more speed.
Eventually you would add in all the other variables like the friction between the two dominoes, the fact that the domino is still being "pushed" and is still falling, and a whole bunch of other stuff.

TL;DR: Friction is more important than weight when looking at these dominoes.

As for the speed in dependence of the friction coefficient:
1.) first ensure, that you change only the friction coefficient, and not the harness/sofness of the material. For example: Filth as a soft material will expand unter the toppling domino, applying more upward force to the lifting end of the domino, than a hard surface would do, that does not expand.

2.) What you effectively create with falling dominoes is a rotational-transitional wave. Its speed is would be defined by something that represents mass of the elements and something that represents coupling stiffness.
a) Higher mass of the dominoes would slow down the wave speed (effect on the translational wave)
b) Higher moment of inertia of the dominoes would slow down the wave speed (effect on the rotational part)
Here the friction comes into play. A domino on high friction surface is pivoting around a point on the surface and therefore
has a higher moment of inertia than a domino pivoting around its center of gravity (Parallel axis theorem).
c) the coupling is highly nonlinear and can only roughly be compared to linear wave. A large spacing could be interpreted as
"soft coupling" and therefore would lead to a slow wave. I guess spacings closed to the maximum possible spacing
would be slower than medium spacings. On the other hand, a zero spacing would create an insane fast speed. The last
domino would move instantaneously with the first one, but this would not be a chain reaction.

3.) For the spacing and speed we need to understand the effects that influence the wave speed, I would guess (in order of appearance):
a) starting speed of the domino, given by pulse transfer from its predecessor
b) reduction of speed by friction with its predecessor
c) reduction of speed by lifting the domino slightly when pivoting around its front corner
d) increasing rotational speed by gravity during falling
e) overlayed decrease of horizontal speed as function of the cosine of the falling angle
f) fraction of pulse that is transferred to the next one as function of its angle
- lower horizontal pulse with larger falling angle
- contact point hight defines how much of the puls is transferred as translational and as rotational pulse
g) part of the overall length, that is covered by spaces and part, that is covered by domioes (which internally have an comparable infinite wave speed). The shorter the spacing, the shorter the effective "falling distance", and the lager the part with infinite speed.

This could lead to totally different behaviours:
* zero spacing: = zero falling distance, last domino drops instantly with the first one
* very small spacing:
triggered with minimum pulse, the first domino could already take (theoretically) an infinite time to just reach its highest point and remain on its (instable) equilibrium. This does not happen in praxis, but it shows, that there exist short spacings with pretty much zero speed. We even could think of a slightly larger spacing, where we just slightly overshoot this equilibrium and get just as much energy from the falling domino as to trigger the next one with the same minimum pulse. This would give a closed to zero speed chain.
* increasing spacing would likely increase speed for a while to a maximumg
* further increase of spacing would decrease speed, till we again reach a point, where the trigger puls is just enough to slightly overshoot the equilibrium, again a "closed to zero speed" chain.

As an alternative: use a pendulum, released with an electromagnet. The pendulum should be constructed as to always hit the first domino more or less at the same point/line, as a domino would. As the speed, the first domino gets from the pendulum is mainly defined by pulse transfer, we can adjust the pulse by changing starting hight of the pendulum and pendulum mass.
A lightweight pendulum would allow more precise adjustment by hight. We could use this setting to observe the behaviour of the speed adjustment. How speed increased if started to weak, and how speed decreases, if started to strong. Adjustment for the experiment should be as to decrease the speedup phase to zero, to have constant speed from the beginning.

Probably someone already wrote this, but a few days ago I thought about the answer to why the row of dominoes on much slippery surfaces cover longer distances:
The forces acting on the domino are 1)the force exerted by the previous domino and 2) the friction exerted by the surface of the table on the domino edge. *Both forces head forward*.
The more slippery the table's surface, the smaller the friction exerted on the edge of the domino. At this point, the force exerted by the previous domino is greater than the friction force, so the angular velocity of the domino (center of rotation= center of gravity) is greater. This yields to greater angular velocity of the single domino and a greater impact with the next one. Now, thinking that this fact is amplified by the number of dominoes in a row makes me think that a row of dominoes on slippery surfaces cover greater distances.

People always emphasize energy conservation, but a lot of the physics of domino toppling is in the frictional aspects.  Have you tried suppressing the bottom sliding by adding a little hinge of tape to the front edge?  I predict the wave goes faster.  There are also interesting dissipative collision and friction effects when a domino's top edge collides with the next one in line and slides down.  Making dominos out of bouncy rubber would make the collision more elastic.  Covering them with teflon (or some such thing) would make them slide better.  As far as I know, nobody has really definitively studied the realistic domino problem.

I think the motion of a single tile is defined by two motions: first one is the pivoting around the center of mass caused by the push of the preceding tile.
In that case there is a friction between the table and the tile makes the rotation slower, so the smoother the surface the faster the fall.
Second component is the push of gravity that makes the tile fall like it's described in the papers and that's what makes the tile go down once the friction stops the rotation completely
Only thing left is mass, my guess is that heavier tiles are faster despite the bigger friction because they acquire more kinetic energy because of gravity, but I'm very curious to see the a more detailed explaination with better controlled experiments!

Hi! Loved the video, and enjoyed wracking my brain around creating an experiment to get representative results.  First, the question that originated the experiment will help to simplify some things. Since you are looking to see what factors impact steady state domino fall velocity, you should ignore data from however many dominoes it takes to reach steady state (in the video you said roughly 20) and the last few dominoes (since they don't fall on other dominoes in the same way the last 2-5 fall further and will skew your results). This first change helps your triggering issue because there should be convergence to a single steady state velocity when triggered at any speed below the steady state velocity, although if it still bothers you, you can achieve better precision with a pendulum with fixed starting height and mass. The second change is to alter only one parameter at a time to get the effect of that single parameter on velocity using a truth-table to construct your test cases (I assume you are already doing this, but didn't mention it in the video, so I thought I would add it). Lastly, I think it would add interest to mark out the center of gravity (on the side of each domino) so we can track the movement of the center as well as that of the leading edge (maybe easier to do that with a pen and jig rather than in video post-processing). Thanks!

It makes total sense that pivoting about the center of gravity would result in faster falling than pivoting about the contact point with the ground: the moment of inertia is smaller in the former case than the latter (because you're concentrating more of the mass around the axis of rotation). Smaller moment of inertia -> greater angular acceleration -> faster falling.

Also, the mass of the domino's matters only to the extent that it influences friction (and if the domino is very light, perhaps air drag). After all, both the torque due to gravity and the moment of inertia are linear in the mass of the domino. So it shouldn't be surprising that heavier dominoes can fall faster under certain conditions.

The reason why slipping is faster
(Physicist here)
I'm going to try to articulate this as best I can.
First, a falling structure's center of mass accelerates at g, this means the upper part of the structure will accelerate faster than g and the lower part will accelerate slower than g.

Second, we don't care how long it takes for the domino to hit the rest floor, we care how long it takes for the domino to hit the next domino.
So, a horizontal motion is more important than a vertical motion.

So the slipping will cause the vertical motion to slow down, but the horizontal motion to speed up because the axis of rotation moves closer to the center of mass.

Because the experiment is done in quantity, you don't need to understand the single domino, because each single domino will be slightly different.

You should try to statistically understand the group of dominoes.

So you can approximate and average the point of rotation which will be somewhere between the center of mass and the bottom tip.

The more friction, the closer the rotation will be to the ground.

When dominoes reach a steady state, they will have an initial angular momentum because of the initial impact and follow the following force diagram:

The lower the coefficient of friction between the domino and the table, the closer the pivot point will be to the center of gravity, which would also coincide with the volumetric centroid, assuming even mass distribution. The more the center of rotation is offset from this point, the slower the individual domino will rotate.

I'm sure that lower friction between dominos also improves top speed when dominoes are tightly spaced, as allowing them to slide against one another lets a toppled domino exert force longer down the chain. That is, less of its torque is eaten up by the force of friction at the interface between dominoes. But then this is another case where things need to be in equilibrium, as the dominoes will want to slide backward earlier on in their fall, which would give that force of friction at the domino/domino interface a greater moment, which would cancel some of the torque from the earlier, forcing domino. It might be interesting to try a test with some high friction "backstop" dominoes at the start which would prevent this from happening.

I think when the domino "digs in" you are seeing the rotational period decrease, which increases rotational period, but since you have only changed the cF between the table and the domino, you may wind up with a higher top speed overall due to the increase in torque this causes. It'd all depend on when the front bottom edge breaks free from the table.

My guess as to why the slippery surface is faster: When the dominoes slip, they are (approximately) rotating around their center of mass. When they don't slip, their center of mass must move forward. In both cases, the domino rotates. Adding the forward translation of the domino means it will accelerate much more slowly. Doing the math on this would be really tough if you try and use different coefficients of friction, but analyzing just two idealized scenarios -- domino rotating exactly around its center of mass, and domino rotating around its bottom edge -- would be much more manageable. 1.) Instead of focusing just on energy (like many comments), momentum is what determines the speed at which the dominoes fall with the same amount of energy. When the dominoes allowed to slip, they "try" to rotate around the center of gravity and you end up having less angular momentum (mass x distance) resulting in a faster turning movement thus making the whole row fall faster. Take a stick or anything long and sleek in your hand and try to rotate it quickly by first holding it by the very end and then compare that to gripping it in the middle and rotating it. It takes much less energy to get up to the same speed when you minimize the rotational momentum and so the dominoes fall faster when they're allowed to slide. Though I would be interested to know if that's true for much longer rows of dominoes. My reasoning is that because you're minimizing the momentum, the dominoes will impart less of their potential energy to the next domino when they collide (of course the total potential energy is the same for a falling domino). It might be that the slippery surface wins in the short run but after the domino row on the grippy surface has built up enough speed it could overcome it's initial disadvantage.
2.) Make the rows much longer. If a different surface produces a 0.001 second difference, it'll be much harder to detect with 10 dominoes than it is with a 100. Also you'll have less variation with different runs since all the minute differences in domino orientation and spacing will even out. The domino spacer you're using isn't exactly precision machinery after all. :) This will of course make it more difficult to fit all the falling blocks in a single camera frame with decent resolution. I'm not sure what the solution should be. You could make it snake back and forth, but that might produce more variation than it eliminates. I suggest a single row filmed from as far as is sensible with your camera's resolution.
3.) A really non-high-tech solution for consistent pushing might be a feather. The idea is that you push it slowly with something that has just enough force to start the first domino to fall over. You want to eliminate the variation in pushing force. One way of doing it without any finely calibrated pushing device is using the absolute minimum amount of energy by slowly just barely tipping the first domino over. Then it doesn't even really matter at what height you're pushing it (as long as it's not sliding forwards when you do so). The downside with this is the difficulty in determining when the first block started to fall. I suggest just ignoring the first block in measuring the time and only considering the second block. It's much easier to tell the exact moment the first domino hits the second one.
4.) A monofilament test wire (a slightly fancier piece of fishing line) is also one option of pushing the dominoes over. Medical examination monofilaments are designed to push with the same force regardless of how hard you push it (they have just the right amount of bend). It would be much easier to aim precisely and are much less random than a feather. I suggest using the lightest monofilament that's sufficient to push a domino over so the force will be as consistent as possible. They are really cheap.
EDIT Actually I like Hevesh5's idea of a very slowly moving motorized toppler better than the monofilament or feather. Go with that one.

In my view the domino chain speed is a function of spacing, stone rotation and speed. The ideal spacing is as small as possible but still provides the energy to just knock the next stone over. The stone rotation is determined by its moment of inertia and Steiner's theorem. The moment of inertia is determined by mass and geometry and floor friction determines the pivot axis and results in Steiner's theorem. This rotation determines where the stone will have the required energy. Stone speed is determined by falling height, stone-to-stone friction as well as air resistance. This looks like floor friction wouldn't matter as it is compensated by the ideal spacing while stone-to-stone friction and air resistance does matter as it determines the speed by which the next contact can be made. This makes a lot of sense as a chain of dominos is locally static but transmits information along the way, thus it is not influenced by friction against the outside world (the floor) but only by the friction inside the system. Conclusion, given you use identical stones, focus on ideal spacing and minimal stone-to-stone friction...in a vacuum ;)

first, I grew up with dominos so I really enjoyed this.  as for the testing, I suggest a pendulum (with round metal ball) to use as the starting force to topple first domino.  two reasons: you get the consistency of gravity, and you can control the impact by how far back you draw the weight.  This should help you control two things in one simple tool: consistency of initial impact, and starting speed of first domino (which may help reach the ramp up speed faster).  I suggest the pendulum string be several feet tall (for more granular control and more horizontal impact) and the release of the drawn back weight be controlled with a electromagnet.  the backdrop should be a grid so you can accurately measure the various draws later.  also, the ball should impact the first domino at the exact spot where a previous domino would strike, and the weight of the pendulum ball should be equal to the weight of one domino.  also, the pendulum string (when at rest) should be slightly ahead of the first domino to mimic the angle of impact of the would-be previous domino (slightly downward angle at POI).  there are micro flaws in this approach, but I think its close enough without having to break out some high tech equipment that may not be lying around in your garage :)

Wouldn't the domino chain reaction go faster on the slick surface since the friction on the pivot point is reduced, therefore allowing the domino to pivot more freely, thus ultimately faster? I'll explain my thought below...

You can clearly see that dominoes on the slick surface pivot more than the dominoes on the grippy surface.This could be a result of a reaction to the lack of friction on the pivoting surface (right corner of domino) which allows the domino to appear to spin about it's center of gravity faster than a domino subjected to friction on that pivot surface. Therefore when the domino is on a relatively grippy surface, the domino slips less, thusly translating the rotational potential about the pivoting axis that is relatively fixed compared to the sliding ( or variable) axis on the domino on a slick surface.

Therefore, the main variance between the two domino sets is the change in friction on the pivoting plane. The slick surface domino has a "sliding" rotational axis, whereas the domino with the grippy surface has a "fixed axis". As a result of this, the rotational axises between dominoes on a grippy surface versus one on a slick surface are in fact different. A result of this difference in pivoting planes means that the center of gravity between both sets of dominos changes as well. The sliding domino has a higher center of gravity (more centralized), meaning it can pivot faster about it's pivoting point than the grippy surface domino. Since the distribution of mass across the pivot point can alter the speed of the rotation, an object with a centralized pivot point can rotate faster and smoother (think about it like a wheel, a center hub will spin more efficiently than offsetting the hub even just a few degrees). Further, due to the small size of dominoes, this difference is minute, (pivoting planes may only be a millimeter or less different) yet extrapolated out over hundreds or thousands of dominoes, this small variation compounds itself into a noticeable difference in speed.

A second possible hypothesis is that the resulting frictional interface between the domino and the surface it is rotating about causes a reduction in potential energy of the system. We know that friction takes energy away from a system by converting some of the kinetic energy into another form of energy (like heat, which is how disc brakes on a car work). Looking at the highspeed footage it appears as though the resting dominoes "hop" once the interaction with a falling domino is initiated. Therefore, in order to move, the domino must overcome not only it's resting state of motion (Newton's first law) but also the energy required to move it from the surface it touches (friction with the surface it sits on). This "hopping" is exactly that motion, overcoming it's resting state of motion. While the domino is in the air, it is allowed to rotate and accelerate freely (assuming the interaction with air is negligent). Yet when the domino lands back down on the surface it must rotate relative to it's contact point. On a slippery surface, the domino is allowed to rotate more freely thus inducing a sliding axis as a result of the rotational energy overcoming the resistance of the surface that it is contacting, whereas on the grippy surface, the domino is forced to rotate about the position it landed on since the domino does not impart enough energy on it's rotational axis to induce the slide. Since friction is working against the rotation (forces are in the opposite direction of the rotation) it can be said that energy is lost along the rotating plane on the frictional surface. And therefore friction along this rotational surface is acting much like a brake would. This would account for while the dominoes on the slippery surface, they "kick back" more than the dominoes on the grippy surface. As a result of this energy "loss" there is less forward potential kinetic energy and the overall system travels just slightly slower on the grippy surface than on the slippery surface.

Friction in this setting appears to act like that of rolling a tennis ball on a glass surface versus a turf surface on slopes that matched in slope angle and slope length. The tennis ball will roll faster down the glass slope than down the turf slope, since the energy imparted by friction is greater in the turf slope, the remaining potential energy that can be converted into kinetic energy will be reduced... Both systems have equal potential energies at the beginning of the experiment, but friction will limit the speed of the ball between the two experiments. I hypothesize that this is the case here as well.

However it could be a combination of both of these factors, or neither of them at all! thanks for reading and i look forward to finding a solution soon!

Here is my thoughts on how to drop a domino constantly.

Take one domino and drill a hole through it along the long narrow side making it slightly top heavy. Attach the domino through a shaft that will suspend it ever so slightly above the table. The domino should still be able to swing forward as it normally would (pivoting on the shaft). Use a pin coming up from underneath the table. The pin should block or prevent the already forward leaning domino from completing its forward swing/drop. Removing the pin—by pulling down—should not introduce lateral force on the domino, but allow gravity to complete the forward swing/simulated drop

Hey Destin - a couple thoughts on your domino experiments:
1. I wouldn't worry about your initial tipping mechanism. As long as you have enough dominoes to get to steady-state, the initial push shouldn't change much.
2. If you don't worry about the initial push, the only thing you can't do is a "race" between two types of dominoes like you did in this video. But it was a little difficult to see. You can probably make up the difference in post by aligning two different runs top and bottom to get the same effect.
3. More slippery domino or surface means less friction, which should make the domino fall faster because the friction with the ground works against the direction of rotation, making them rotate and fall more slowly.
4. That being said, the dominoes with more friction should fall further forward for the same reason, allowing the grippy dominoes to be spaced even further apart, (slowing them down even more?). You saw the opposite in your tests so far, but that may have to do with how close the dominoes are spaced - if they are too close for this effect to matter, the more slippery dominoes may end up falling "further" because when the last one or two get "squished out" at the end of the drop, they can slide further before stopping. This may mean the speed difference between high and low friction also depends a lot on spacing.
5. I feel like heavier/lighter dominoes shouldn't play a huge roll. Think of the effect of dropping a heavy and light ball of the same size (Veritasium has some great videos on this). They end up falling at the same rate. But we're not dealing with spheres here, so it's possible rotational inertia has some different effects, and my instinct is way off.

It’s simple. It can be explained by the conservation of momentum. The reason why ‘slipping’ ‘increases the speed’ is because when it pivots on it’s centre of mass, there is a smaller moment of inertia, therefore it can rotate faster and displace the next domino quicker, even though the clear domino’s have a slightly higher mass. It’s like a figure skater spinning with her arms open vs arms closed. She can spin a lot faster with her arms closed because she has a smaller moment of inertia in that instance.

I've watched this video a few times, and I think I know why it's faster on a lower friction surface (and also why different colors fall faster)
On higher friction surfaces, the dominos maintain contact with eachother after beginning to fall, creating friction between the dominoes themselves and slowing the fall each falling domino, reducing the terminal velocity of the domino chain by removing energy from the forward translation.
On lower friction surfaces, the domino rotates easily around its center of mass, and the individual dominoes contact each other much less, rotating out of the way of each other until it can no longer be avoided, reducing the friction against each other and keeping more energy in the forward translation of the domino.
If the dominoes themselves were also made of a lower friction material, this effect would be bolstered, albeit minimally.

Start the tipping by using a pendulum. It would be easy to make an adjustable trigger so that it falls exactly the same way every time. Use at least 30 dominos, though preferably 100 for proper accuracy.

This way you can accurately test the speed of any kind of domino on any kind of surface. You can also test speed with or without acceleration by adding extra dominos at the start before you start measuring.

You can also compare the level of acceleration and even deceleration at different initial speeds by dropping the pendulum from different heights, giving the dominos varying amounts of inertia at the start.

It might also be an idea to try different distances between the dominos, different dimentions, different sizes and different weights.

All in all, these are the things you measure: Speed, pivot point, acceleration, deceleration. (Ideally measure the last two in length, time and number of dominos)

And these are the variables: Initial pendulum height, distance between the dominos, ground surface, domino surface, size, dimentions and weight. Heck, even humidity levels might make a measurable impact.

I am late to comment on here but here are my thoughts.
1. Triggering: A consistent trigger could be made from from a slow moving motorized pushing element. Something that is going to repeatedly push the domino so slowly that once the domino's center of gravity passes over the edge that it is tilting on the domino would accelerate away from the pushing element so kinetic energy from the pushing element is negligible.
2. You should consider doing a study on the steady state conditions of the dominos and figure out the maximum number of dominos that need to fall over to reach steady state as a function of the friction and domino mass and then add 10-20% to that number and use that for all of your tests. Only film the section that is within the steady state region. This sounds like a time consuming process but dominoes are a time consuming past time in the first place...

On the slippery surface, it is allowed to rotate around its center of mass, so there is little energy loss and the rotation of the block is faster and so it hits the next block faster. On the grippy surface, the block is forced to rotate more around the right bottom edge and therefore you have a longer rotating arm which rotates slower with the same energy. Also the center of mass has to rise a tiny amount to get over the edge. If it slips, the center of mass stays basicaly at the same height so again, less energy loss. And other effects I'm sure.

Think about domino's in space:
Put a domino free in space and poke it. It will rotate around its center of mass.
Hinge the same domino in space, it needs to rotate around an "off-center axis", therefore rotating slower (or needing a higher impulse for same rot speed).

Or think of the ice-skater pulling the arms closer. He speeds up, same with the domino. Rotating around center of mass is faster for same impulse

This means that the domino on the slippery surface is able to rotate faster because of the smaller rotational inertia, and therefore will "fall" faster down the line. Low friction surfaces makes it so that there is an added step when it's rotating around its center of mass until it's pushed down by the previous domino, having to change between static and dynamic friciton, as seen at 8:12-8:15, this should have 'terminal velocity' oscillating periodically around it's value as the dominoes don't get settled in an orderly manner and energy waves travel back and forth, as opposed to what they do on higher friction surfaces.

Also domino finish friction should affect how potential energy is transmitted between them. So eventhough more friction between domino and surface should be faster, as said around 9:08, more friction between dominoes should make it slower, as energy gets wasted on this friction.

In any case the biggest factor for clear ones going faster should be it's higher mass, which means there is more energy stored per length measure, so when it's being released its terminal velocity should be faster.

Measuring time between contacts gives a great indication about if 'terminal velocity' was reached.

I'm thinking the variables you'd want to consider would include:
-Friction of the domino on the surface
-Friction between dominoes when they hit
-Mass of the domino
-Spacing (which really determines where the domino gets hit with a lateral force, which would determine the moment applied, which would determine how fast it rotates, which would determine the momentum going into the next domino)
-Where the first domino gets hit
-How much force the first domino gets hit with (probably not as important once you get to a steady state, but would it affect the steady state you get to?)

Not sure if this is mentioned but fluid dynamics is also at play here if you want to reduce the inconsistency of pushing the first dominos. The dominos moving at a varying speed when pushed is very similar what you can see in traffic jams which oddly enough, is fluid dynamics. Youtube "Phantom Traffic Jams". It's a phenomenon of individual units in a forward moving system colliding and basically bouncing back and forth onto each other until the energy of the total forward flow equalizes. Aka the total speed that the dominos will fall will speed up and slow down throughout the system unit the imbalance of energy is equalized. So the longer you make the system and the farther down you start your study, the more accurate your findings will be and variability will be reduced.

My thought for a way to make this a completely controlled experiment went as thus. Acquire about 6 different pieces of material at least 2 feet long. Wood, Plastic/Laminate, Rubber, Foam, Carpet, and Metal. Then cut the material into 2" by 24" strips. Put 2 sided tape on one end then tape the strips right next to each other on some sort of board and put a ruler on the front of the board and some sort of grid system behind it. Then, for the knocking mechanism, I thought you could cut a thin slot in a piece of plywood, then 2 rods next to the ends of the slot. Secure 2 small rods in the holes. Put a small spring in between the rods and the slot, then fasten tubes at the end of a flat, thin piece of wood and place that wood on the rods. Then set up the wood some way that it is a set distance from the dominoes. This way when the wood is pushed through the slot it will be resisted by the springs an should give a relatively uniform knock over each time. With all of this you could set up different types of material dominoes next to one another and compare. You could also test different materials and see them side by side.

A few ideas for consistent domino toppling:

1) Ping-pong ball pendulum. Fix a ping-pong ball on a stick or string, suspend stick/string from above, pull the ping-pong ball back to a consistent angle and release for a simple repeatable and gentle touch.

2) RC airplane/car/robot servo. You can hook one up simply with a servo tester, no programming required, and position the servo arm such that at the end of its swing it just barely contacts the first domino. That way you get just a simple "touch", and no externally-imposed acceleration in the initial topple. Put a short arm on the servo for the slowest tangential velocity. OR put a cam-shaped arm on instead for an even slower touch-speed.

Hi Destin, a couple of things:

To consistently start the dominos, glue a small ball bearing to a thread to make a pendulum. Make a rig to suspend the pendulum above the first domino at a consistent height, with an electromagnet holding it back a fixed distance (and height) from the domino. The fixed height gives it a fixed impulse when you turn off the electromagnet and let the pendulum swing.

Secondly, a domino on a sticky surface will rotate about (close to) the leading corner rather than the centre of mass, so it has a much greater moment of inertia and so takes longer to rotationally accelerate.

Trigger mechanism: Best one I can think of is a mass on a string or a pendulum. Then you can run nearly the exact same trigger every time. So a string dangling from a nail with a nut on the bottom and a protractor behind it to measure your angle.

Other cool things you could do. See how fast they go uphill vs downhill. And check it with a coefficient of friction higher than 1, like on a piece of tape or on a sticky surface.

Take a servo motor and a micro controller (like an Arduino) and fix the location of the servo motor. In most cases a servo motor comes with rotors you can put on top of the servo easily. You can modify the rotor to fit your needs, but it is not necessary in our setup.

I think you're nudging them too hard at the start.

Basically, the way I see it, dominos are supposed to fall ONLY due to gravity; basically, once you lean one over enough the center of gravity is beyond the bottom edge, gravity pulls it down by its center; at the same time, because the bottom corner is touching the table, it pushes the domino upwards, but because the two forces are not acting on the same point, a torque is created. The thing is, if you graph that out, all the force vectors are pointing perfectly vertically, which means there should be no horizontal motion; this also means friction shouldn't be an issue at all, in theory.

Because you push the first domino too hard, and near the top, it actually starts pushing it sideways, and making it spin around its center of gravity, as you said; I think this is what is causing the slippage. The way I see it, in a perfect domino setup, each domino would give the next EXACTLY enough force to nudge it out of balance, and you'd let gravity do the rest; if all your dominos are perfectly identical and you set them up at exactly the right distances (larger distance means more time to accelerate, meaning a greater force), then each domino should fall in exactly the same way, and there should be no overall acceleration in the system.

In practice this is probably impossible, partly because making perfect dominos at perfect distances is impossible, partly because you wanna do turns and piles and other crazy stuff, which messes this all up. So I think in a practical setup friction matters because it counteracts any additional horizontal motion that may get added from the nudges.

I suspect one important factor for how fast dominos fall is their hardness. Harder materials deform less under impact, which gives them an elastic collision characteristic. Elastic collisions are more efficient in transferring energy than inelastic collisions. Think about the difference between dropping a steel ball bearing on a hard floor versus dropping a lead shot. Since the steel ball is harder, it will bounce much higher than the lead ball, where energy is wasted deforming it (slightly) and lost as heat. Similarly, ordinary dominos are most likely made of ABS, while transparent ones are acrylic, which I do believe is significantly harder. This makes the collisions more elastic, so the acrylic line falls faster.

The pigments used for colors can potentially make a notable difference in material properties, including hardness. Even though only a small amount of pigment is used, thus probably not influencing density noticably, the presence of the pigment molecules disrupts and changes the structure of the polymer. This can be viewed in much the same way as adding just a few percent of carbon to iron makes steel, a much tougher material.

A quick thought: You should verify whether the dominos are solid plastic or if they're hollow in the middle to save material costs. A hollow domino is less rigid than a solid one, which drastically affects collision elasticity.

I think this is the prevailing behavior but of course this is only based off the analysis of one domino, ignoring things like friction over time.

Destin, I think you are changing too many variables at once in your test. You should try and select as many dominos as you can of roughly the same weight and put them on surfaces with different coefficients of friction. A servo with a digital PWM controller/driver (RC controllers aren't quite exact enough) would allow you to contact the domino the same way every time.

As far as my hypothesis on the physics... On a perfectly smooth surface with rounded bottom edges the rotation would be purely around the CG and there would be no acceleration in the system. You would see both a rotational and translation momentum transfer (again assuming perfection) that would be equal to the force that you put into the system. However, as you increase friction the pivot point becomes further away from the CG which will allow more acceleration due to gravity therefore resulting in an eventually faster fall. Same thing goes for heavier dominoes; the contribution of gravity will be more significant. However there has to be a terminal velocity, so what is the constraining factor? Possibly loss of energy during the momentum transfer? You must also take into account the elasticity of the dominos as that will effect how quickly and efficiently the momentum is transferred. On a smooth surface however the moment of inertia is smaller and therefore the angular speed will be greater for the same amount of energy.

Hey Destin

First of all, very cool video; I liked it a lot. Here's my idea on how you should try your experiments on Dominoes:
1- For the triggering, I suggest you do it the same way (pushing with a stick), or with a falling block. You can also try with the stick and look how they would fall with the stick hitting the block at different places (top of the brick, bottom or center) and different speeds ( like throwing the stick or gently pushing the block). See how any of these variables makes a difference.
2- If you don't want to change how you trigger the chain, do this: Have a long start section that is let's say 1m long. First, make sure the fall is not accelerating after the start length, so do some tests to find the suitable length. Keep this section consistent between all of your tests, for example opaque plastic white color for all bricks, on hard floor, and average spacing. Choose a color that is the same color as the background, so that you don't see them when the test fall is started. After this long section put your test bricks. This way you have an actual brick that is triggering the fall in your test section.
3- In each test, start your timer when the first test brick touches the second test brick. I think this is more accurate than looking at when a brick starts to fall. Also calculate the timing for the rest of the bricks when they touch each other (like each 100 bricks fall in 1.5 second).
4- In all of the tests, have a longer test section to have a longer duration for the experiment. That way your accuracy for the time of falling and measurement of speed is better (consider the error of 10ms in 100ms vs 1000ms)
5- for each test you should keep all variables constant except one.
a. In a series of tests, keep all bricks as blue plastic (in contrast to the background color), same spacing, same starting length, and just change the ground material.
b. In a different series, keep the ground material, length, spacing and brick material consistent, but change the brick colors.
c. Try bricks with different spacing, but keep everything else the same.
d. Try brick with different materials (like plastic, wood, metal, acrylic, etc.) I think the impact of each brick on the other one has an effect here.
e. I'm sure the air drag has an effect on the falling speed ( assume the whole chain was in water) but I guess the change in that variable is very negligible (due to air temperature and humidity)
6- If you are trying side by side tests, take the video from top (to see both rows better) and again calculate your timing for when the bricks touch each other.
7- One of the things I like to see is where the block pivots around (the instantaneous rotation center). See if this point changes for different blocks, and different frictions.
8- Investigate the impact between the blocks: Is it a very fast touch (big force, short time) or slow touch (small force, bigger time). I know we can't measure the force from the camera, but we can measure the time they touch each other.

It’s known that the dominos fall at a fairly constant averaged rate overall (over the course of a full build). It’s constant enough to predict the rate of fall more or less accurately. With a row of single dominos on a similar surface, after the initial acceleration, the rate of fall levels out to a constant.

Knowing that, it’s highly unlikely that your initial trigger mechanism is going to have a measurable effect after the velocity stabilizes x number of dominos into a line. I’d wager that after a set number of dominos, it doesn’t matter how much energy you put into the first one. They’ll stabilize regardless.

Hey Destin, I'm thinking the slower rate with higher friction has to do with the way the moment of inertia of the domino changes depending on the point about which it is rotated.

Rotating about the end results in a MOI of 4x that of rotating about the center. Therefore, with the same force applied to the same location on the domino, the one on a lower-friction surface has a greater angular acceleration. The moment arm of the applied force from the previous domino about the point of rotation is twice as long in the floor-pivot case as it is in the center-of-mass pivot case (i.e. 2x the torque), but since the MOI is 4x, the angular acceleration is cut in half.

The way you topple the first one can have an effect on how the motion propagates.

If you push the first one slowly, it should swivel about the front edge, and the toppling will accelerate until it reaches steady state, as you've already demonstrated; if you hit it the same way that it gets hit during the steady-state portion of the line, I don't think there will be any acceleration of the line, and you would see the same slippage at the base of the tile; if you hit it with a sharp impulse, it will probably swivel mostly about its centre of gravity, making the base slip back significantly. That sharp impulse one would probably cause a fast toppling motion that will decelerate as it propagates down the line.

Or I may be wrong...

Those three cases would make for an interesting High speed camera study.

The slippery surface is moving faster because the moment of inertia is smaller. If the domino is rotating about a point closer to its center of mass, the MOI is less then if it rotates about a corner. So, there are two conflicting effects. The slipping domino has further to fall before hitting the next one, but it has less MOI.

I love that this video captures the element of evolving experimental design that is so important in real science. I think a lot of people don't realize that experimental science is an iterative process where your previous results inform  your next design until you start getting really clear results.

A possible trigger that is consistent but simple is a rigid pendulum with a backstop to prevent over swinging. An adjustable stop at the start of the swing should allow you to restart the pendulum quickly and consistently while allowing you to vary the force (clamp L bracket to backboard?). This allows you to fix impact force, height of impact, and follow through. I'd wager lower impact force and follow through would minimise the effects of your trigger on the system, but also lower starting velocity requiring longer rows if you want to accelerate to a near steady rate.

EDIT: Addressing the acceleration issue (but adding complexity): You could use a dummy domino at the start, one that is actually hinged to the surface, to simulate a consistent domino at the start of the run. Calibrate your pendulum to hit so that the dummy domino falls at approximately the terminal rate of the real dominoes. Should hopefully reduce artefacts from the trigger while shortening the required number of dominoes.

Although the slipping action means that less initial energy is transferred forward, I think it might make sense that the slipping domino causes the line to fall faster. It has to do with moment of inertia, if my hypothesis is correct. A mass spinning about it's center has a much lower moment of inertia than a mass rotating about it's end, so more total energy is translated in the long run. So, a slipping domino means more energy rather than less, probably?

Looking at Hevesh5's pinned comment saying that larger spacing on grippy dominoes is faster, the above may also explain that. The time from one domino to the next is the time from initial impact and zero velocity to final impact with some acceleration and energy. A short distance means lower acceleration but also lower time. My hypothesis is that for slipping dominoes there is more rotational acceleration so gravity cannot accelerate it fast enough to outweigh the benefit of a quick impact and short spacing. The initial energy transferred to the domino is mostly kept, so the domino can just pass that on without needing gravity to do much work. However, for grippy dominoes, there is much less rotational acceleration, so a wider spacing to allow the acceleration due to gravity to kick in results in a faster time. The initial energy is mostly wasted in moment of inertia, so the domino has to wait for gravity to impart more energy to it again, yet it results in the dominoes falling faster as a whole, because it needs that energy from gravity to keep it going quickly.

Potentially, there are some instances where the mass and friction and acceleration are just right that a very small spacing could be fast, a medium spacing is slower, and a wider spacing is faster again, or vice versa.

It seems to me (once seeing your footage) that there is a small amount of slip which amounts in the highest speed.

If my intuition is correct, the slip allows the domino to avoid the part of the fall where the domino has a low amount of tilt, and a low acceleration. however it would be important for it to grip after the initial impact in order to translate that force to the next domino.

I suspect that materials with low static friction, and relatively high kinetic friction would increase the speed, because they would allow the domino to arrest it's slip once it has recovered from the impact with the previous domino.

I also suspect that sharp edged dominos would be faster than chamfered / rounded edged dominos.

A possible hypothesis: the heavier weight of the clear dominoes are, in aggregate, causing the last dominoes to fall faster.

While the force of gravity acts equally on both the heavy, and light dominoes. The heavy dominoes are transferring more force to the next domino in the line because of its greater mass (F=ma).

So while both the heavy and light domino alone will topple at the same rate, because of the higher mass of the clear dominoes the a set of heavy dominoes will fall at a greater speed.

If the domino pivots without slipping, the moment of inertia is measured over the full length of the domino. If it slips, and rotates about the CG, then the moment of inertia is smaller - so it will accelerate faster and the chain will fall faster. I think this is obvious and confirmed by your tests. But the weight thing I find much more difficult: obviously light dominoes will require less energy to rotate faster, but then light dominoes pass less energy to the next domino, meaning it will accelerate slower; that maths is too hard to just guess, it needs some proper calculating.

I believe that when the dominoes slip and rotates about the center of gravity it is faster because the moment of inertia is lower than when the domino rotates about the edge. This results in more torque required to rotate the domino at the same angular velocity. As a result, the dominoes that slip fall faster compared to the dominoes that pivot from the bottom edge.

As for starting the domino chain reaction, it might be best to use a very slow motor to push over the same single domino for every single experiment, so that the energy transferred will be low enough that it doesn't knock the other dominoes out of position, and it would be very consistent at transferring the same amount of energy. It would probably be favorable to use the same starting domino for every test in case there really is a difference between the different dominoes, so by using the same domino for every test, you are imparting the same initial knock onto each subsequent domino.

I disagree when you say that you change from a rotation to translation due to friction. The actual difference between slippery and adherent surfaces seems to be a change on the axis of rotation. For slippery the axis is closer to the center of mass, while for adherent is at the bottom corner -- like in textbooks.

In this case the change in speed may be interpreted as a change in the moment of inertia of the rotating dominoes. Because the moment of inertia increases when the axis of rotation moves to the bottom corner, for the domino to have the same energy -- which comes from the gravitational potential, hence is roughly the same in all cases -- it rotates more slowly. And I believe that the energy loss due to friction on the slippery case is not enough to cancel the effect of changing the rotation axis, then the slippery rotates faster.

To estimate how many dominoes you need to achieve terminal velocity you probably can check the video you show at 10:09. I believe it has to do with the number of dominoes moving while one of them is being toppled -- I counted about 20 in this particular video. I think the weight of all these dominoes participate on the toppling of the next standing one, then you should count back from the standing one down to the fist steady toppled. Also, this is a soliton system and maybe it would be worth it to check soliton properties to figure that out too. There is also a more practical -- or maybe not -- way to check this; did you notice that the sound they make when falling changes frequency? That definitely tells you the speed the row is toppling.

The fact that it partially pivots around its center of mass wasn't much of a surprise, but it got me thinking about the contact point between the dominoes and spacing. What setup covers the most distance in the shortest time and what setup tumbles the most. If the dominoes are close, the contact point will be high, and therefore the individual domino will never accelerate to a high velocity before impacting the next. Where as far spacing would result in a lower point of impact and an higher individual velocity, which would result in a quicker acceleration of the next domino due to the increased falling speed, but also a longer distance to be covered before impacting the next, therefore maybe a delayed acceleration of the next. So it might be that there is a somewhat constant tumbling pace and a different coverage, or it might be that dominoes that are close will eventually reach the same falling speed but might just do it slower. If that is the case, it would be fun to see the correlation between distance covered, the number of dominoes tumbled, spacing and time. Would the closely spaced dominoes reach the same falling speed as the far spaced, in the same amount of dominoes? or maybe in the same distance? Is there a constant there or are they somehow correlated in a graph. There is so much to to ponder here, too much for a YouTube comment. So many variables, but I am almost certain that it can be fitted into a relatively neat equation, but if we add different weighted ends it could get even more interesting. Thanks for the video, I really hope of do some great testing on this. It is so simple yet there is so much to test and try :)

In order to consistently topple the dominoes, you would have to push the first domino just beyond its stable point (push its CG just enough to cause toppling). This is probably much easier said than done. It might make more sense to have a much longer line of dominoes and only look at the dominoes after the line (or wave) has achieved terminal speed (steady state speed) with the high speed camera. That way you can compare steady state speeds and figure out general trends in the behaviours of different coloured dominoes.

My hypothesis is that on a surface with more friction, the force of friction causes a net reduction in the torque about the CG which causes each domino to topple slower as compared to on a low friction surface. It would be interesting to study the difference between rolling (as in the case of a wheel; where more friction is better) vs. toppling (as in the case of these dominoes; where more frictions seems to slow it down). I think in the end it will come down to which type of domino can create the maximum torque about its CG to facilitate toppling. This will obviously depend on the:
- mass of the domino --> which is affected by the material/colour
- the friction between the surfaces --> affected by the surface AND the material of the domino
- external torques due to the previous and next dominoes in line

I'm excited to see what comes out of this in the end! Did not expect this to be an interesting problem :)

Thoughts on the trigger mechanism:
Electromagnet release is the most consistent I can think of
trigger should be hinged at the bottom for better consistency
perhaps use a domino with a bit of metal attached that is held at an angle by the magnet, cutting power allows it to fall
input of more force at the outset of the trial allows it to come up to speed faster = shorter runs

Thought on trials:
top cameras make better visuals for tandem runs
tape hinges at the leading edges would allow you to eliminate slippage as a variable, giving a more textbook scenario
stickum should yield a similar effect with much less effort

Thoughts on experimental order:
first, do different colors of the same material achieve different speeds (eliminates mass and friction)
second, does different coefficient of friction affect speed (eliminates mass)
third, does mass affect the effect of coefficient of friction (suggest center weighting dominoes of the same material)
fourth, does mass affect speed (use tape hinges)

On getting a more consistent starting force for the dominoes, three ideas: 1) A marble on rails at a steady slope. Simply have the marble (or ball bearing) at the top that is released (probably by pulling a pin) for a consistent, gravity assisted hit.

3) an elastic band to pull back your stick or what have you (I like this the least because the elastic gets worn and it's probably going to produce far too much force).

Some of the difference with regard to the grippy surface or the slick surface is the resulting centre of rotation. If the domino grips at the corner it then rotates around the corner not the centre of mass. This difference in rotation affects the moment of enertia of the object, which would affect the speed it rotates.

You could use a pendulum swing (Newtons Cradle) as long as the height the weight drops from is constant the energy inputted on the dominoes will be the same. note the other factor you will need to consider is the height of the point of impact on the domino and how does that impact the result.

If we assume that dominoes on high-friction and friction-less surfaces get the same (kinetic) energy while falling, it would make sense that the ones on friction-less surfaces reach a higher angular velocity, since they rotate about their center of mass instead of about their edge, which means their moment of inertia is (4 times?) smaller. On top of this, friction should dissipate some of this energy,  making the dominoes on high-friction surfaces even slower? Obviously, angular velocity does not equate linear velocity of the row of dominoes, as this change in axis of rotation also impacts where (at which angle) a given domino will touch the next one, but it's something to consider :)

One creative idea for consistency of trigger is drilling a hole through the side of a domino toward it's edge and running a small bar through (creating a hinge), then setting it up to dangle a consistent distance away from the other dominoes. Then you raise the hinged domino to a consistent height and release it, causing it to swing down and hit the first domino at speed. This can be calibrated to force the dominoes to accelerate to maximum speed more quickly, without altering that speed.

With regards to the physics involved in the dominoes that "slip", if the "unhinged" (being freed from the hinge effect of friction surfaces) dominoes rotate around their center of mass, that means that the distance from the edge of the domino from the fulcrum is shorter. At first this alters the rotation path of the edge to be longer from point A (upright) to crossing line B (the face of the next domino) thus increasing the time it takes to hit the next domino over it's hinged counterpart. However with it's more distant mass being closer to the fulcrum (like a figure skater pulling in their arms for a spin), the domino also rotates at a higher speed thus decreasing the time it takes to hit the next domino. The changes should mostly cancel each other out except the increased speed of the domino also increases the effects of air resistance on either side of the fulcrum as compared to the slower-moving hinged domino, slowing it down. On the other hand, the increased distance from the fulcrum of the edge of the hinged-domino also increases the amount of torque effect that air resistance has on it, thus further complicating matters.

Then you have to consider the changes in momentum. With a higher amount of torque from the edge of the hinged domino it imparts more of it's energy to the next one, but with a higher amount of speed, the unhinged has more energy. Then there's the matter of where it hits the next domino, since the hinged domino's arc path causes it to hit the next domino higher up, increasing the amount of torque it applies to the next domino over the unhinged version. Lastly, the angle the domino is traveling and thus how perpendicular it's velocity is to the desired direction of movement (horizontal), where the unhinged domino's edge movement is angled more down than the hinged version and thus less energy is passed in the horizontal direction.

TLDR; By my estimations, given all other factors like height, mass, and air density are identical, dominoes which remain hinged should individually fall more slowly, but as a set topple more rapidly, than dominoes which "slip" or become unhinged from the friction of their resting surface. Of course, I hope I'm wrong.

WRT triggering, I suspect a simple pendulum device made with a very heavy base (or mounted directly to the table), and a pair of 'stops' would be a simple way to provide a consistent amount of force. Essentially -- imagine pair of right triangles, suspending a small crossbar (perhaps mounted on low friction bearings), the crossbar supports a 'T' shaped pendulum with a 'kicker' which protrudes in front of the perpendicular leg. The 'T' bar interferes with the front and back legs (the back leg is the hypoteneuse of the triangle). so when it fires, it impacts, kicks the first domino, but doesn't follow-through. The back leg ensures a consistent 'wind up' -- simply adjust the weight at the base to adjust the force applied.

I see lots of comments suggesting motors, pendulums, and more complicated triggers for that first domino. A much easier way to trigger it would be a spring mechanism. So long as you know the spring constant and the contraction distance, you can then know the exact energy imparted to the first domino.

As for why the propagation speed varies counter-intuitively to surface friction, think about a rod rotating about a pivot. With the same impulse at the same spot, will that rod rotate faster if the hinge is at the base of the rod or at the middle? It rotates faster about the middle, right? This translates into the dominoes that slip on the surface rotating faster and thus propagating faster. The dominoes that don't slip are forced to rotate more around their base than their center of gravity, which means the impact energy is distributed throughout the mass of the domino.

I don't think this is a constant, however. There may be some relative size of domino to rotation speed/impact energy at which the greater impact energy of the non-slipping dominoes will be more significant and contribute more to the propagation speed than the faster rotation of the slipping dominoes.

Off the top of my head, slipping dominoes should go faster (at least at the start) for the following reason. When the domino does not slip, the center of gravity actually has to rise and fall, and that results in part of the energy going into potential energy rather than all of it being in kinetic energy, and overall slower horizontal motion of the top of the domino. When the bottom slips, the domino simply rotates, and the top of the domino goes at maximum speed, and reaches the next one faster.

To test I would first organize all the dominoes by mass assuming they are all the same size. Then I would do a long line of each mass of dominoes to determine at what speed they stop accelerating. For accuracy this will also have to be tested on each surface with different frictions.

Second I would use a set piston to fire at the same speed the dominoes fall. I would have the piston wide and flat like a domino so it hits flat and even like other dominoes and test it again to see if that decreases the time of acceleration. This way you will not have to set up as many dominoes for each test. This piston, or actuator, or whatever you use should be mounted firmly to the table with a block in front of it that the first domino can be firmly and squarely set against. So each test can have the same start speed depending on if the acceleration rates vary between the different masses of dominoes.

Make a long track of dominoes and watch in slo-motion to see how many dominoes are in motion at any given time, and then measure the distance between the first one in motion and the last one in motion. Drop a domino from that height - and the speed it reaches when it hits the ground will be the maximum speed that the dominoes fall. You can't do this starting from the first domino, because as more dominoes come to rest on each other, there is more force pushing against the next domino, thus, the speed increases as more fall. However, as they come to rest, they begin to support each other against each other, cancelling the weight of those that are not in motion. Once you account for that, I'd be willing to bet that the resulting speed of falling dominoes is equal to the speed of a falling domino dropped from the height of the line of moving dominoes.

The most basic mathematical model to see why reducing domino friction should increase the speed:
Consider a vertical rod of mass M and length L. The rod is toppled after a fast (assumed to occur instantaneously) impulse hits it at its top. Call the impulse magnitude P and the center of mass velocity v.

Frictional case - enough friction to keep the bottom stationary:
The moment of inertia of a rod about its end is I = M*L^2/3. Denote angular velocity about the bottom (pivot point) as w.
Final angular momentum = L*P = I*w
Final angular rotation w = L*P/I = 3*P/(M*L)
The top of the rod has a velocity T = L*w = 3*P/M
The center of mass rod velocity is v = T/2 = (3/2)*P/M

Frictionless case:
The moment of inertia for a rod about its center is I = ML^2/12. Now w is the angular velocity about the center of mass.
Final linear momentum = P = M*v
Final angular momentum = (L/2)*P = I*w
Final angular rotation w = (L/2)*(P/I) = 6*P/(M*L)
The center of the rod velocity is v = P/M
The bottom of the rod has a velocity B = v - (L/2)*w = P/M - 3*P/M = -2*P/M
The top of the rod has a velocity T = v + (L/2)*w = 4*P/M

The top of the rod has a larger velocity in the frictionless case, which should translate into a faster domino toppling speed.

Intuition:

The impulse at the top of the rod sends the center of mass into motion, but it also causes rotation. For the bottom of the rod in the frictionless case, the rotation is backwards and has a larger velocity contribution than the center of mass motion. As a result, the bottom gets a backwards velocity.

When there is friction, this will counteract the motion of the bottom of the rod. That implies that the frictional force is forward (not what you might expect). This forward frictional force produces a torque on the center of the rod opposite to the impulse causing a slower rod rotation speed compared to the frictionless case. The forward frictional force also increases the center of mass velocity.

So friction has two effects: to increase the center of mass velocity and to reduce the rotation. These have opposite relations to the velocity of the top of the rod/domino. Thus the result depends on the relative magnitude of the two, which depends on the moment of inertia. There is a threshold that separates the two possibilities, i.e. whether friction increases or decreases toppling speed. This occurs when the center of mass moment of inertia I = (1/4)*M*L^2. Here the bottom has no velocity even in the frictionless case, so friction isn't needed and contributes zero force, so it doesn't affect the toppling speed.

Edit: now that I think about it, that threshold looks like the maximum possible moment of inertia for any shape of length L about its center of mass; concentrate all the mass at the two ends and that's what we get. So we won't have any situation in which friction could make the toppling faster, at least in this simple model.

To make your trigger impulse consistent, use a heavy metal ball pendulum with a short period, no more than the distance between your blocks. Hold the ball back with an electromagnet. Interrupt the power and the ball swings the exact same each time.
Or, a rubber band 'gun' with the band attached to the end of the 'gun' placed at the exact same distance for each test.
In either case, you'll achieve nearly identical impulse to the first domino for each test.

I think you'll find the less base friction, the faster the fall and run. The more weight, the slower the fall and run, until the initial impulse is replaced by the impetus of the weighed domino hitting domino and it will level out to just slightly slower than a lighter domino line.
The lighter domino will also scatter more when they fall and the last one will be propelled further, because F=M*A and for the heavier slower (acting under the same impulse) domino that A becomes much smaller and the M is only slightly larger.

So you could have a light 50 domino line on a felt surface next to a heavy 50 domino line on a slick dry erase board and the heavy will finish first. Switch the base and the light line will finish first by a larger margin.

Also, count the end of the run when the next to last domino moves the last domino. Easier to see than the domino landing flat.

The way the dominoes are moving reminds me of the wood block video where you were shooting it off center and measuring how high it went. The difference is that it's horizontal and as the supporting lower half of the dominoes rotates it comes off the floor and the dominoes falls. The forward momentum is passed forward independent of the rotational speed. There comes a point where the rotating domino collides with the next one.
The line of falling dominoes is laying on each other which combines their weight. The shape is like the air gap in front of a tire up to the point the dominoes make contact. That length of a wedge has to establish for the max speed to be reached as that's the max 'gravity wedge' weight(dominoes laying on each other).
There's a couple things to measure: the ramp up time to full speed, and the max velocity of the face of the wedge. The surface friction may be slowing down the rotational speed of the dominoes. The domino on domino friction, as the rub in the wedge, probably has some effect on the max speed and time to max speed.

The reason friction causes the dominoes to fall faster is because the effective rotational inertia is higher. With high friction the pivot is at the leading edge, whereas with low friction the pivot is closer to the center of mass. The pivot being at the leading edge results in a larger radius for the same mass, resulting in a higher rotational inertia.

I would start them using a light pendulum released from a fixed position. Constant drop height, constant mass, constant gravitational acceleration, so you'd have a consistent impact velocity and starting impulse.

The reason a domino with less friction falls faster is because of conservation of energy.
at the limit of zero friction (a frictionless surface) the domino will rotate about it's center of mass with a rotational inertia of m*L^2/12. for a given impact energy the velocity of the edge will be say v1 (and an angular velocity omega= 2*v1/L).

at the limit of infinite friction, the domino will rotate about the edge that's on the floor. in that case its rotational moment of inertia is m*L^2/12+m*(L^2+B^2(/4=m*L^2*(4/12) +m*B^2/4 (parallel axes theorem). where B is the thickness of the domino
this means the moment of inertia is more than 4 times greater than for the no friction case.

Since energy is equal to 0.5*I*omega^2 (half of moment of inertia times angular velocity squared), the angular velocity of the perfect friction case is less then half of that of the no friction case.

now we finally get to the linear velocity:
the linear velocity is omega*r (the angular velocity times the radius from point of rotation). in the case of no friction this is a little more than L/2 since the rotation is about the center of the domino.
in the case of perfect friction the radius is L (from the hinge point to the top of the domino).
this is exactly 2 times that of the no friction case.

now remember the angular velocity of the frictional case is less then half that of the no friction case. which leads to the fact that the linear velocity is slightly lower in the frictional case.

Reason why the slipping dominoes fell faster than the non-slipping:

moment of inertia of a rod (analog to domino) about its center: (1/12)*ML^2
moment of inertia of a rod (analog to domino) about its end: (1/3)*ML^2

More rotational inertia for domino about its end = more time to angularly accelerate = more time to hit next domino = slower overall fall rate

Therefore: less friction should result in faster domino falling speed
