Consider the two suggestions below:

1) If you want a constant impact like the one you are trying to achieve, use a 'Pendulum hammer'. Make a pendulum whose motion is restricted between 180 degrees and 270 degrees. You can probably add a little extrusion to the pendulum to act as the impact head. Raising the pendulum to 180 degrees each time will give you a consistent impact velocity. Also, because the impact will occur at 270, you'll always get a horizontal impact. For a smaller impact velocity, you can mark different angles between 180 and 270 for your starting position.

2) I think that the way a set of dominoes should be set in motion is by having the first one topple with zero initial velocity. This means that you'll need to push the first domino with the bottom pivot point at rest till it reaches the unstable configuration in a pseudo-static fashion and then release it. This would be more difficult to achieve because of two reasons. 1) The pivot point (bottom-right corner) might translate if the friction is low and 2) Achieving pseudo-static motion is difficult. I would use a tiny stopper at the floor for the first domino and a geared down servo for pushing the domino at the very top of the domino (to increase the moment arm from the pivot point)

Okay, as far as a consistent actuator, take one domino and drill a small hole in it about half way through, then insert and glue a small magnet in it.  Next, make an electromagnet and place it near the domino with the permanent magnet with like poles facing each other.  When power is applied to the electromagnet, the domino will fall forward.  The speed at which the domino falls can be adjusted by the voltage and/or distance.  I think this will give you a consistent push.  Temperature will most likely have an effect, but I think it would be negligible unless there is an extreme difference.  I doubt the temperature will vary that much in your house.

You also need to factor in air temperature.  A higher air temperature will reduce friction, but it also could introduce turbulent air that could vary each test. You'll need to do testing in much colder temperatures, preferably in a vacuum.

I think it actually makes sense why the less grippy dominos fall faster. Let's take the extreme limits of zero friction and perfect friction (no sliding at all): then, as you noted, the zero-friction dominos tend to rotate about their center of mass, and for regularly-shaped dominos, that's the center of the rectangle. Meanwhile, in the perfect-friction case, they fall over the bottom corner. Moment of inertia is higher for objects about their end vs. about their middle, so for the same force (the domino's weight at any given angle), the domino rotationally accelerates less quickly. I'd have to do the calculations, but I think the rotational acceleration is a bigger effect than the sliding backwards, which is why the more-slippery ones fall faster - the rotational acceleration somewhat follows an exponential growth because it's an inverted pendulum, so changes in angle due to an initial quicker rotational acceleration would be the dominating factor over any linear or quadratic factor, which I think the floor's frictional effect is.

Actually, now that I think about it, it might also have to do with the height of the domino, too. Imagine an enormous fifty-foot tall domino on a zero friction floor. It wouldn't want to rotate, but it'd still slide backwards a bit quite readily.... I think? Uh... actually, I'm not sure; intuition quickly breaks down with weird setups like that.

A question: why would more mass mean a faster speed? As PE(gravitational) = mgh, and KE= 0.5mv^2, wouldn't the mass not matter as all that would matter is the gravitational acceleration and height to influence the velocity? I would think that since two different colors and different clear vs. opaque dominoes probably have slightly different chemical compositions, that would relate to a different frictional coefficient, which would lead to a different amount of energy transferred. Maybe that would be the reason why the clear moves faster than the opaque? It would be interesting to find out the coefficient of static friction for each type if paint, etc.

As for how to test it, I guess in the case of relieving mathematical headaches, a mere comparison of speeds could work where by the same set up of one domino triggering two lines of dominoes would work, whereby the front has a slippery surface, whereas the back has a friction-ful surface.

Friction is not a key factor except when determining its pivot.

Couple Ideas from a Mechanical Engineer:
First, more friction makes domino fall slower because of increased moment of inertia. The moment of inertia about the center of a rectangle is less than the moment of inertia about it's edge. The larger the moment of inertial, the slower it rotates, the slower it hits the next domino.
Second, the dominoes accelerated initially because each successive domino has more weight behind it. However, it doesn't keep accelerating forever. At some point, the speed averages out and can be used as a constant. If the chain was longer, this problem would be fixed. If a timer was started on the 25th domino and stopped at the 50th, I'm confident results would be much more consistent (assuming all else is held constant).

Hello Destin!
I am TheRealMcJoni, a domino builder from germany and a great fan of your videos. It's so great to see dominoes on your channel! :D
I really love the idea of super-slo-mo dominoes for a speed analysis. I was going to point out the flaws of your first experiment with the acceleration of the dominoes and the inconsistent start, but i was glad to see you pointing that out just a few moments later :D

First of all, to Sprice bashing 'us europeans' ^^: It's not about the paint or the dye, it's about the material of the dominoes. Each color of the dominoes has a slightly different mixture of plastic, at least here in germany (In europe, the BulkDominoes that you have aren't as popular due to high shipping costs. There is a different manufacturer here, but i'm guessing the dominoes still act the same and the differences are not significant.)
Second, i think the color aspect is by far the smallest factor of the three you listed. I'm sure, the floor and the spacing have a way bigger impact on the speed of the dominoes than it's color. On a gym's floor (this is, where most of the bigger domino events take place) a line of dominoes with the standard distance (the distance you get with the swagger stick :D) falls at about 63-64 dominoes per meter with 1m/s, no matter which color. (At leasts, thats what i'm calculating with ^^)
There is one video, where the difference in color was measured (again, with european dominoes). /watch?v=VLrU8si8rgc
There you can see, how small the difference is. However, it is possible that all those times were just sheer coincidence and the material has no influence at all. To get accurate numbers, a bigger experiment would be necessary. (I don't know, maybe that's what you are looking for ^^)

Now for the tips for your experiment:
I'm guessing, a domino line of 50cm to 100cm would be good as the dominoes will surely fall at a constant speed at the end of the line. And that's exactly where to put the ruler, at the end of the line. With that high speed camera, you will get so accurate resultst, i'm really looking forward to it! :D
For a consitent start, I'm guessing some kind of simple lego or k'nex construction that topples the dominoes is enough to ensure, that the dominoes are always toppled equally.

Welcome to Michigan!

First, I would like to say that I love your channel(s) and videos. They are very informative and educational. I recommend your channel to everyone I can. That being said, I have always been critical about controls in experiments. Whether it's your channel or an episode of Mythbusters, I sometimes see flaws in the control, but there is usually no way to express it so that the creators would read it and try to correct it. You pushing the dominoes was the first thing I noticed. Since you're timing the dominoes, I would think an electronic trigger/release system would be in order. Perhaps you could have an automated release for the dominoes, that also triggers a timer, but also triggers the camera. The camera shouldn't be as important, but I wanted to throw that out there.
Another thing I was curious about was temperature/humidity and surface area. If you were in garage and we're filming this over the course of several hours, I'm sure there were temperature and humidity changes. I live in Nashville and I know. ha ha
I would recommend trying the experiment again, except in a more climate controlled environment. If indoors, be wary of air vents, ceiling fans and floor movement. About the humidity...
I would think that if you were in a garage, certain meteorological variables would not be constant. This would affect material surfaces, thus creating a difference in control. Think about how wood or metal reacts to moisture and temperature.
Wrapping this up, I would suggest an indoor, climate-controlled environment and an automated, synchronous release system for the topple mechanism and the timer.
Thanks for making excellent educational material!

I may have a theory. The energy in each domino is given to it from the kenetic energy from the domino behind it, and the domino behind that, and the domino behind that, until we hit the beginning of the chain, where the energy in the entire system first came from.

My hypothesis is this, if the domino pivots on a high friction surface, then the domino as a whole looses energy via friction therefore slowing it down. The domino would loose speed gripping the surface, but because the domino is already tilted gravity pulls it back down translating more potential energy into kenetic energy. The first couple end up with more kenetic energy than the last because of gravity, until the kenetic energy in and out equalizes at about 20 dominos. Thus it would benefit as a conservation of motion, if a domino slid and instead​ rotated over it's center of gravity.

As for the weight issue, my hypothesis is, if a domino is heavier, then it requires more kenetic energy to top over, thus adding more energy to the system as a whole, speeding up the process.

Remember your angular mechanics! If it rotates about the COM, there is significantly lower moment of inertia.

In the case of perfect slippage (which is approximately a rotation about the COM) the tangential acceleration of the top leading edge is approximately v=(h/2)ω, where h=height and ω=angular velocity

In the no slip case, the rotation is about the bottom leading edge, i.e. v=hω.

I think the first guess (that the propagation speed will go up with no slip) would be inaccurate because the rotating arm length has doubled. But moment of inertia goes up faster, thus angular velocity and acceleration will decrease as the square of the rotating arm length, where MOI could be the over-riding factor.

Hi Destin, the slipping domino, while rotating around its centre of mass, has a lower moment of inertia than the not slipping one, which is turning around its edge. This is because the moment of inertia depends on the distance of the mass from the axis of rotation squared. Therefore the slipping domino should at least "spin" faster, because it does not take that much momentum to accelerate him to the same angular velocity. Now the difficult part starts: The distance between the top edges of the dominos beeing fixed, the dominos turning around their bottom edge need to turn for a smaller angle than the ones turning around their centre. Now the maths: The inertia: I(centre)=(m*R^2)/12 , I(edge)=(m*R^2)/3 , with R length of the domino and m the mass. Now the big assumption on my side: The momentum of one domino transfered to the next one is about the same in the slipping case as it is in the case with high friction and a fixed edge (I dont really think this is true, it should be a little less than the domino not slipping, because the slipping domino also moves back at the bottom and therefore despite having the same angular momentum than the other one it could transfer less of it to the next domino ...). So with the same momentum p transfered we get the same angular momentum L for both of our cases (also because it is conserved in any closed system, which, unfortunately, is not really the case here). With a formula for the angular velocity w=L/I and I(centre)=(1/4)*I(edge) we get a factor of w(centre)=4*w(edge). Now lets see by which angle they need to turn to get to the next stone: Using trigonometry we get: a(edge)=sin^-1(d/l) and a(centre)=sin^-1(2*d/l) with d the distance between the dominos and l the length of the dominos. The rotation around the centre only uses half the length of the domino to get to the next one, which gives us the factor 2 in the sin^-1.
Now we put the angular velocity and the angle in one equation and we get: a=w*t therefore t=a/w and therefore t(centre)/t(edge)=(1/4)*sin^-1(2*d/l)/sin^-1(d/l). This does not help us that much until we use a little approximation for small angles, which are given in our case if d is much smaller than l: sin^-1(c*x)~c*x

This all leeds me to the assumption that the factor t(c)/t(e)~1/2

This of course is not the one and only truth, its just an assumption for really close dominos which perfectly conservate the momentum created by the first one tipping over. In reality each domino adds some more momentum by beeing pulled down by earth and when the row reaches "terminal velocity" the same amount of momentum is transfered back to the air and the material they stand on. But I hope this little calculation gave some insight or ideas to people who want to take the concept even further. Also the result, while not beeing that representative, is at least intresting, and subject for proof or disproof.

This is also an inertia problem.  If the domino is perfectly slipping, then it rotates around its center of mass, but if it perfectly grips, then it rotates around one edge. I think it makes sense that the skipping dominos fall faster. Rotation around a center point instead of the bottom edge would be faster for a given amount of imparted energy due to lower moment of inertia. Now I think there probably is a tradeoff here with how effectively a domino rotating in this fashion collides with subsequent dominos, but it looks like it leads to a net increase in speed.

I think if you think about the domino the same way you think about the sear of a hammer-firing action, it makes perfect sense. The energy into the domino has already been delivered by the one behind it - the material density dictates its energy retention, and the coefficient of friction for the floor material dictates its contact. If the motion of the domino overcomes the floor material's friction, it "breaks" loose and releases its stored energy at once. Otherwise, the stored energy is dampened by the motion's overcoming the friction between the floor material and the domino.
As a trigger mechanism you could use a pendulum and for the speed, you just have to find out after how many stones it stabilizes.

The ones that slip more ROTATE faster but with less energy, because: 1. the friction on the surface actually slows down the rotation, 2. the rotational energy is lower as the center of rotation is in the middle of the domino. Therefore the slippery ones should accelerate faster, but the MAX energy should be faster on the stationary ones, because the absolute rotational energy is higher due to the longer distance to the center of rotation if the center of rotation is on the table. Not exactly sure how that affects the maximum velocity though, but my guess is that if there's more energy that should also slightly increase the max velocity. At least that's my intuition, no math behind it :) Curious what your results are though, and whether I'm right or not.

Hey Destin! Thanks for doing a video about our event - it’s really great to see dominoes getting more exposure out there online :D I had a further question for you to investigate, perhaps with your high speed camera. Dominoes can be set up vertically but they can also be set up horizontally so that they’re twice as wide horizontally and half as tall. They still topple well with the same spacing, though not as well on slippery surfaces. One of our builders tried timing sideways dominoes falling and found they fall at almost exactly half the speed of vertical dominoes. I was kind of surprised because I figured there were more variables at play than just how tall the dominoes are. My question is - was it just a coincidence that reducing the height of the domino by half reduced the speed by half? Sideways dominoes seem to slip far less, and it would be interesting to see an examination of all the variables at play and the difference between vertical and horizontal.

By the way, I see why the frictionless domino's fall faster. It's all about energy, and considering that it's a pivot; it to top portion is allowed to fall forwards and the bottom portion allowed to rise backwards at the same time(which is what ALL domino blocks want to do, regardless of friction), the energy will not be absorbed much at all until it hits the next block and transfers it's energy. But if we introduce friction on the bottom half of the domino, then the same motion will happen, but the upwards/backwards motion of the bottom part of the pivot (block) will be hampered by friction, which will absorb some of that energy, and actually counteract it, which means it takes the upper half of the pivot a little bit longer to hit the next block, as some of that forward momentum is gone. I wish I could draw a model, but that's at least part of what is happening.

So the question here, is how can you make a constant trigger system, without the use of expensive or custom manufactured parts?

One thing I can think of is taking advantage of water pressure when gravity is creating the pressure. No pumps or anything. Just a bottle of water, some tubing, and something at the end like a piston that moves when the water pressure is high enough to push it. So you would need like a valve to open. It would not be perfect, but it would output the same amount of pressure each time to the piston.

Another way, that also isnt perfect, but would be pretty close, would be to use something as a "kicker" and put it on a pivot. When lifted back to its trigger point, have something it rests on that is always at the same height. When it is removed, the "kicker" would fall down and knock over the dominos. But you would probably want to put something on the front of the kicker to hit the domino, and then a stop so it cant go over a certain point. That way it always stops at the same spot. But the hit might be too aggressive.

To get rid of the inconsistent start, you need a longer pre-measured phase, so perhaps 300mm between push and measurements starting. You'll also want a post-measurement run, as you don't want to be looking at the final domino which probably lands inconsistently. The measurement for time should be when the domino at 0mm (in the measurement zone) starts moving to when the first domino after the measurement zone moves.

That was really interesting! I have never really thought of the dominoes slipping.
As far as a consistent domino initiator, ideally you would likely want to take out any initial velocity component by only allowing the center of mass to affect the speed. To do this maybe you could use some sort of servo to push it very slowly until the domino effectively tips over at its “natural“ speed you should only need to tip the middle of the domino past the bottom corner, setting up a servo to do that should give consistency.
As the dominos fall in the beginning I would think the speed would mostly increase until the first domino fell to the ground completely, as each domino falls on the one in front of it there is a stacking effect so the 5th domino actually has the last 4 dominos pushing on it – at least until the first domino falls as mentioned before.
As far as the slipping goes for the increased velocity I can think that is there is less friction then more of the energy should be transferred. Initially you were thinking the bottom is moving backwards so more of the energy is moving backward. I think the domino instead of the forces just being translational the domino has translational momentum and angular momentum. The domino spins so it is not that the bottom if the domino is moving backward, the whole domino is spinning and moving forward those forces should be additive when contacting the next domino in line.
As far as the mass effecting the speed that may be because of the overall potential energy being higher. If the dominos are the same height at the beginning and the end for both a lighter and a heavier domino the potential energy change will be greater for the heaver dominos. Since almost all of the energy is transferred to kinetic energy the dominos should move faster with a heavier domino. At least until you account for friction where there is more friction for a heavier domino…
Something else I thought about is the material could possibly an influence on the dominos falling ie the bounce from the dominos colliding (the coefficient of restitution I think it is called). Also the elasticity of each domino could change things - how much of the energy goes into bending the domino vs just translational movment. That factor is likely too small to be a measured though… at least until you make human sized dominos (next video?)
A lot of physics going on for sure. My thinking could be entirely flawed but those are some of my thoughts on the subject. I am excited to see what is to come!

hey Destin, here some idea about trigger AND physic explanation/experiment.

IDEAS FOR TRIGGER: possible solution is a solenoid, but you have to find a way to dump part of its energy or will make the domino fly. Use a power regulator to bring the voltage down, like to 3v, this avoid (big) fluctuation of force caused by the input source (like battery discharging) influence. That should be something you can do with less than 10$. As input is digital, maybe you can even hook it up with a microcontroller controlling the camera and the solenoid. Also multiple solenoid could be hooked up in series, BUT i'm not 100% sure they will be reliable in timing; better to have one than push a level that will push a vertical bar )to start multiple domino line (that you should record from above).

IDEAS FOR PHYSIC:
You need to find where acceleration get to 0, and focus on that spot; already finding this spot will give all the information we require.

About heavier going faster: is a gravity-feed engine, make sense

About pivoting going faster: it is true more energy is transfer if not translating, BUT if it translate is because it want to move in a more efficient spot to move ITSELF; i guess that when it translate it become a better lever, so it will translate the energy faster and potentially better; also look how much "travel" is done in the z (gravity) axis, because this is where potential energy is translated to rototranslation energy. This should also vary on the THICKNESS of the block.

also the distribution of mass would be interesting: you could drill some hole (and maybe fill partially with some denser counterweight to keep the whole block mass constant) to analyse how the different distribution affect: i would try more mass in center of mass, more mass in estimated center of rotation, and then just generic top/bottom heavy. I expect the top heavy to perform better, as it has more potential energy and in the most unstable equilibrium.

I think it might be worth thinking about the parallel axis theorem. When the dominoes are slipping, they pivot more about their centre of mass - moment of inertia is smaller. But when they grip - they pivot about their edge - moment of inertia increases. This leads to a lower angular acceleration per domino and likely a lower linear topple speed.

Think of it this way, It's not like a race car trying to get more friction, but more like a curling stone trying to preserve momentum, no energy is being added to the system, just preserving the kinetic energy provided from the potential energy in the system from the dominos being stood up.  More weight means proportionally less drag from air.  I think a key component in the slipping dominos moving faster is that moving the center of mass of a domino is drag in the system.  Rotating around the center of mass is more efficient and hits the next domino faster so lower friction is better.  This probably becomes less advantageous the further apart the dominos are placed.

If the dominos don't slip, they probably accelerate faster since more energy is transfered to the next domino and also the previous domino hits the next one a bit higher, so the inital torque is greater. The wave of falling dominos is faster if surface is a bit slippery, since the rotate around the center of mass and are not slowed down by friction, therefore the kinetic energy of the previous domino is trasfered to the next quicker.

How to trigger - make a very light pendulum on a stiff metal rod, test how far you need to extend it before release to topple the first domino every time, mark that spot and rig a quick release. The quick release could be anything, even a skewer blocking the pendulum rod. It won't be perfectly repeatable, but because you'll need, for example, to extend it by 2", the minuscule differences in pendulum release shouldn't matter. In essence, the pendulum acts like a lens on light, magnifying the triggering motion, so that it's controlled on a different level of magnitude.

Also, block the pendulum at the trigger point and fix the first piece so it always rotates against the bottom edge (use a hinge or an axis) - more on this later.

About measuring the speed - you either need a longer chain of dominoes to let them achieve their top speed or adjust the pendulum increasing its momentum, so it transfers more energy to the first piece until you see an acceleration only on the first few pieces. You still need some, but that might cut down on setup time and allow you for more repetitions, which I believe would be more important.

And another thing - you don't need to focus only on the speed of progression. You can focus on each individual piece triggering the next one. How much time passes from when the piece starts moving to when it reaches the next one? Where's the point of contact? Does the point of contact influence the speed of rotation of the next piece?

Remember that first piece on a hinge/axis? Make a couple of different ones rotating about a different point, like make one with an axis through its centre of mass, and another in between the centre of mass and the bottom edge. That way you have a repeatable way to see exactly what happens at a single point of progression when one piece triggers another.

Finally, my prediction - I'd say that both increase in mass and decrease of friction would increase the speed of the progression, but the friction would have a more significant influence. I'm thinking it all comes down to how fast a single piece can trigger the next one. For that, you need the piece to have enough momentum to overcome the next one's inertia, as well as speed so it reaches it faster. Luckily, speed also influences momentum, so speed would be essential here and have a greater influence than mass. Now, because the pieces are so close together, our piece will trigger the next one regardless of whether our piece rotates around (in approx.) the bottom edge or the centre of mass, but in the latter, there's less inertia that the rotation has to find against, so I believe that's faster. However, if the pieces were further away from each other, there would be a tipping point on the graph (piece spacing vs progression speed), indicating a spacing at which an increase in friction translates to an increase in progression speed, because the difference of axis of rotation would have a much more pronounced influence on the angle of contact between two pieces, and thus the momentum it can pass to the next piece.

P.S. - propagation velocity is a term I just made up (maybe it's used elsewhere, I don't know?) to describe the average horizontal velocity at which the dominoes run into each other during their individual states of kinetic motion because the relative velocity of each individual domino is only nonzero for a very short period of time. A quick glance makes me believe the difference lies in the inertia: slipping bricks meet less resistance in the next in line, because the bottom of the next brick is free to rotate. This means the tops of the bricks maintain more speed, because all in all each brick has less problem to turn around its CoG than if it were to grip the ground.

As for the ignition mechanism: connect the poking bar to a rotating mechanism (something similar to bicycle pedals, for example), so that it pulsates a steady distance as the pedals are turned. One full turn of a pedal means one pulse of the bar. Mark the flooring to make sure the first stones are always equally distanced from the bar, and mark the pedals to make sure their starting angles are similar. Hang a non-changing weight on the pedal, and let go. Voilá: similar starts in every experiment.

Finally: I would like you to figure out if there's some sort of terminal velocity, so to speak, because I suspect that flipping bricks meet less resistance in the next brick (because they don't grip the floor), but gripping bricks lose less energy to the flip, and I wonder if this results in or cancels out a difference in 'terminal velocity' of the line of bricks.

OK ... let's take things to the extreme and consider a ten foot long domino. Regardless of the material or mass, a 10 ft domino that rotates around a point at it's end (domino with better frictional contact) will rotate slower than the same 10 ft domino that rotates around a point closer to it's center of mass. My Theory (based strictly on intuition): even though the "slipping" domino is losing some force by it's base moving in the opposite direction, the slight loss of force is made up by a higher rotational speed - although the amounts we are talking about would be extremely minute. ... Also; although it seems the force and movement we are considering is a straight line or translation of force, it's actually a rotational force being transferred from one domino to the next in a straight line. If that's the case then the full mass of the domino is used in the transfer whether it's slipping or not. That is, only if the falling domino strikes the next above it's center of mass. It becomes a translation only if the stationary domino is hit dead center of it's COG. If that would be the set-up, then the domino with better friction will change that translation force into a rotational force faster than the slipping domino (it must do that in order to fall), and the line of slipping dominoes is more likely to falter and stop prematurely.

Other observations from the video: the slippage around the pivot corner has a couple of possible effects. More slippage decreases the translational distance the domino needs to move to reach the tipping point, which should make the domino tip faster. First of all, if you want a consistent way to start the dominoes to fall, some sort of apparatus that uses a pendulum needs to be built. The weight of the pendulum can be dropped from a set height and it can fall consistently, ignoring temperature, humidity, etc. The pendulum can be placed so that it can hit the first domino at a desired point, preferably near the top of the first domino. This may take some experimentation to get right...type to weight, length of string, etc.
Second, it looks like you have 3 variables: spacing of the dominoes, surface, and mass. You'll need to eliminate the variables by selecting the same kind of domino for your cascade. This may include weighing each domino with a sensitive scale and grouping them by mass. Take one group and go with that. Your spacing and surface selection are easier because you have a domino spacing guide and you can choose what surface to use. Once you have your setup, don't change anything until you've run enough cascades that you are confident you've eliminated your variables.
During your experiment, you have to figure out the acceleration and velocity part. With your high speed camera, you'll need to determine at what point in the cascade it stops accelerating. Then you should be able to determine velocity of the cascade (dominoes per sec).
Once you get consistent results, you can change one of your variables. Lather, rinse, repeat.
I imagine once you are done with this, you could write a paper characterizing how dominoes fall. 😉 Good luck.

Setup:
Compressed air at specific pressure at set distance for pushing speed.
Do trial runs to see where the speed maxes, you need to measure that max speed, so that means you need to set that many dominoes before (and a bit extra to account for variation in falling speed). Next you might want to side-by-side set up 2 sets to compare OR time the falling of the final domino as the end point. You could measure the falling of a specific domino with a laser timer to achieve consistency.

To begin your comparison you must assume that mass, friction AND distance all affect the system and design your experiment around that. In your trial runs, you should also try to find additional affects that might occur in your lab. (like lighting, air pressure or temperature) If these also affect the speed, you should control these too.

When you have found you controls in your trial experiments and find that you always get a consistent time with a specific set of dominoes you can start trying new sets. Try clear dominoes against red ones for example and measure the mass difference and repeat. You should find a correlation with mass and time if mass indeed affects the speed.

You could also try the next spacing after yet another trial run to find the max speed domino requirement. This way you could test this. I would recommend trying about 10 spacings if you can to get a graph.

Same for friction, though you will need more trial runs to find the max speed. Try different surfaces and measure their static friction with a newton meter to compare to. This way you can compare the friction measure.

With this experiment design I'm sure you will get the results you are looking for.

When the domino is allowed to rotate freely around it's centre of mass (like on a non-grip surface) it's time to contact point is lower because it effectively has a shorter rotation, so when it's forced to pivot around the leading edge (high friction surface) it effectively travels the same speed over the same distance but through a longer arc, resulting in a slightly slower cumulative time. Instead of asking how long it takes each domino to move forwards, I think the correct question is which one reaches the floor first, or rather, which on completes a full rotation fastest, bearing in mind that that's what the domino is trying to do there's just something in the way (the next domino). I'd be interested in hearing your thoughts on that.

My intuition on the influence of the friction on the final velocity:
Imo the friction of the underground should decrease the final velocity (at least for small distances of the dominos, on the other case later), because the momentum of inertia of the domino rotating around the lower front edge (the case of high friction) is much higher than the momentum of inertia around its center of mass (assuming no friction at all), so in the latter case the domino should begin rotating much faster.
In the case of high friction the maximal possible distance of the dominos should be higher though, since it uses the full length of the domino when rotating around an edge, and just half the length (ignoring transferred linear momentum) in the friction-free case. This is an easy measurement that tests my intuition.

About measurements of the final velocity and the corresponding motion of the dominos:
If you only want to look at the motion of the dominos when they have reached the final velocity, you just need to have enough length of dominos under the same circumstances (distance, surface material etc.) before your measurement. The inconsistencies in triggering won't matter if it's just about the "final state".

About the acceleration process:
The most consistent way of triggering the dominos I can think of would be to give the first one the least starting momentum possible when tipping over the front edge , so you might do this for example with a piezo motor. This might be overkill though, just pushing the first domino very slowly might be accurate enough.

Destin, An idea for setting off the dominoes in a consistent way would be to use a hobby servo, like the SG90 mini servo. Mount it on a simple plywood stand that can be clamped or screwed down to the test surface. Rather than using an expensive RC controller and the radio set, you can get servo testers for around $5.
The servo is activated by a potentiometer, that allows you to alter the speed at which the servo moves. Whilst this might be good for trying different starting methods, the human controlled motion could introduce another variable into your research.
To eliminate this you can control a servo with a microcontroller like an Arduino. A little more expensive but with the addition of a push button switch you can have the Arduino control the speed and motion of the servo. The code for this or 'sketches' are all available online.
An Official Arduino will be around $30 but for those on a budget, a clone of the open source design can be found on ebay for under $5.

A simple mechanical solution would be to build a pendulum that is released with a spring type clothes pin. To stop the pendulum knocking down more than the first domino, add a stop, with padding. The only issue with this, is if the pendulum has too much stored kinetic energy when it hits the stop, the energy will be dissipated as vibration of the whole structure. This would possibly knock over more dominoes, or the vibration would add another variable into your experiment. Also if you want to get very serious about reducing variables, air pressure changes between tests may influence the speed of the falling pendulum. Higher pressure air, may slow the pendulum introducing slightly less energy into the system. But now we are getting into minute variables now. I don't know how precise you want to be.

For the sake of controlling the amount of energy added to the system by the initiation, I'd go with the electo-mechanical Arduino system. I think the idea others have listed for a pendulum is a good one, but there is a lot more to think about!

Specifically, you need to consistently place the domino track relative to the pendulum. This is important for 2 reasons: First, obviously if it needs to swing the same distance before initial contact each time in order for the force to be consistent. Second, the angle of the pendulum's swing relative to the face of the domino will determine how the force is translated to the domino track. This problem is further compounded by the need to swap surfaces, which suggest a solution should be found outside of markings on the surface.

Some solutions to problems I see:

(I will refer to left as the side the pendulum is set up on and right as the side the dominoes fall towards.)

1) If you go with a pendulum you probably want an apparatus that will allow a pin to be placed in the path of the raised pendulum to hold it at a consistent height until the pin is pulled to release it.

2) For relative domino track/pendulum placement I think the pendulum should probably be attached/bolted to a sub-surface to ensure it is stationary and the testing surfaces can be placed on top of the sub-surface and adjacent to the pendulum apparatus.

3) The guide you're using to lay the domino track should probably be longer than any of your test surfaces so when it is placed on a test surface (and held flat against the base of the pendulum apparatus) it hangs off the end of the test surface suspended above the sub-surface. Then you can mark on the sub-surface where the guide is expected to hang off (or even better have a receiving apparatus that cradles it so it can only be in one position) so you can control the alignment of the dominoes from the left side to the right side in relation to the pendulum (the guide keeps them straight, but you need to keep it straight and positioned the same relative to the pendulum).

4) Test surfaces should all be the same thickness to avoid the pendulum striking the domino at different heights (I think this may be pretty important due to the way the dominoes try to rotate, a higher strike would get more leverage etc...)

5) For bonus points, monitor humidity because, if I remember correctly, friction decreases as humidity increases (not sure if the relationship is linear either, its been a while).

6) Anything else you or others can think of!

A domino that slips rotates about its center of gravity as opposed to rotating about its edge. The moment of inertia about the center of gravity is smaller than that about its edge (see parallel axis theorem). Therefore a slipping domino will have a faster angular velocity than a pivoting domino.

However, a slipping domino's reach is half that of a pivoting domino. As a result, the maximum reach for a slipping domino (approximately half of its height), would require 90 degrees of rotation, compared to 30 degrees for a pivoting domino. Since the distance function is sinusoidal (reducing horizontal velocity of contact edge as the angle increases), we can expect that pivoting dominos will perform better relative to slipping dominos with larger distances between dominos.

We can see that the stack of fallen dominoes reinforces the falling domino and can assume that potential energy is not lost in a slipping domino compared to a pivoting domino. Mass shouldn't effect speed in a vacuum.

Hypothesis:
-slipping domino will be faster than a pivoting domino when spaced close together
-pivoting domino will be faster than a slipping domino when spaced far apart
-mass will have a negligible effect on velocity once the falling dominos have reached steady state

Many people are suggesting to use a pendulum, but I don't think that's a good idea. To study this phenomenon you must have a precise measurement of the initial momentum of the bricks. The pendulum is a good idea in the sense that you could easily calculate its velocity at any given point and you'd know its mass. However a pendulum would produce a very long impulse on the brick. What you want is an istantaneous (pardon me, I don't know if that's correct in english) impulse.
You could ask your local university to use an air cushion track. You'd have to weight the cart and you could use laser time gates (they usually have those mounted on the track) to measure the speed of the cart before the collision. Furthermore you could have consistent initial velocity using a spring to launch the cart and an istantaneous impulse by using stops on the track. By doing this you'd have one variable under control. I know it's overcomplicated, but that's how a physicist would do it :D and it would also be entertaining to watch. Alternatively you could skip the cart and use only a spring... but I don't think you're that boring, are you?
To measure the frequency(t) function of the fall, you could employ a graphical method with a frame by frame analysis of the phantom footage or (and I'm not sure if this'll work, but I'd love if it did) you could use a microphone, drop the recording on ardour, do a fourier analysis of the pitch that the bricks produce when they hit eachother, plot the results somewhere and then fit your data to calculate the acceleration (df(t)/dt).
Good luck!

We'll, I can't tell you how you can get all the math worked out (math isn't my best subject at school you know), but I can suggest how you can see the difference in velocity of all the different factors.

As suggested by Steve, different factors should cause different velocities. This difference in velocity can be very very small when looking at a small scale / set of dominoes (like the 20 dominoes you used). But if the difference in velocity between two factors is like 0.01%, then if you lay down 1000 dominoes, one will be twice as far as the other after a certain time.

So what should you do? Hire or arrange to get a hall like the one you were at in the beginning of this video and lay down multiple rows of dominoes (all with different factors such as different materials of dominoes and materials the dominoes stand on), each row being 500 - 1000 dominoes long. Then let these rows fall down at the exact same time and you'll be able to see with the naked eye which row goes faster than the other.

Hope this helps!

There has got to be a "terminal velocity" to domino's falling. When they first start falling they gain speed but it's obvious that speed doesn't continually increase. finding this speed will help your research.

also, the friction of the surface that the domino's are on is important because it holds the bottom of the domino still, therefore keeping the center of gravity more forward and higher making it fall faster. However, since the domino's increase in speed they will transfer more energy to the next domino ABOVE it's center of gravity. So you can see where I'm going with this, it will make the next domino slip further on its bottom edge. There must be an equilibrium of these forces after a while, that's what I mean by "Terminal Velocity" finding the amount of domino's it takes to get terminal velocity will help cut out a lot of variables. my guess is that 3-4 feet might do, but that is an uneducated guess.

For the trigger, you just need something to isolate the inconsistent input from a repeatable output. You could do it mechanically with the release of a compressed spring, or you could do it electrically with a motor (probably the easiest if you have a small motor and an Arduino lying around). If you're feeling elaborate, you could use a PWM stepper motor so you know exactly how hard and fast you're hitting the dominoes without getting into electrical machine theory. But it really just has to be repeatable; as long as it's the same every time, the specifics don't matter as much.

Unless you're going full-bore into the tribology, in which case you can use all the help isolating variables you can get.

Speaking of, I have a theory about why they seem to fall faster on a smooth surface. Assuming the energy of a toppling domino is roughly constant once the cascade reaches steady-state, a domino with one end anchored by friction will force its other end to overcome more inertia than it would if it was rotating around its center of mass. The same impulse overcoming more inertia should mean a decrease in velocity.

I have an idea for you.
When I was in my second year of college, we where testing the restitution ('bouncyness') of materials for a paper using marbles of equal sizes. That experiment was the first thing that came to my mind when I saw how you tipped the dominoes, right before "that's not consistent!".
My original idea was to film the marbles over a striped floor. Knowing the distance of the stripes and filming it to get time, we could measure the speed of the marbles before and after they impact. To move the initial sphere, we struck it like a billiard ball with a steel rod. Showing the footage and the calculations to our teacher, he came up with the idea of using a ramp to launch the first ball and let them impact on a flat portion of the channel. And so we did. And it worked beautifully.

Friction doesn't matter in this launch system, so you just launch the marble at the same height on the ramp and you get pretty consistent results.

Man, that was a cool experiment to do.

When the domino pivots about its centre of gravity, the average distance between a point in the domino and the pivot point is shorter than if it pivots about the base. This allows it to have a lower moment of inertia and therefore "spin" faster with the same amount of energy, thus more quickly transferring the energy to the subsequent dominos.

Destin, as someone who builds dominoes somewhat seriously (my record is 12,000), I first just want to say thank you for devoting an entire one of your awesome videos to this subject :)

I have some suggestions for the experiment. First, you're absolutely correct that the domino line needs time to accelerate before it reaches a constant speed. If the dominoes are spaced very close together, this might require more dominoes than you would expect. I would let at least 10 fall over before you begin measurement. If you do this, however, then you definitely do not need to worry about how much force you use to knock over the first domino (so long as you don't hit it with an extremely large amount of force). By the time those first 10 or so dominoes have fallen over, the line should be toppling at the same speed regardless of how hard you pushed the first domino.

I would also suggest that, when you're timing the line of dominoes, you should stop the clock when the second-to-last domino first touches the last one. I wouldn't stop the clock when the last domino hits the ground. Since the last domino has further to fall than all of the others, it ends up rubbing against the second-to-last one a good bit before it hits the ground. Therefore, if you wait until the last domino hits the ground to stop the clock, your results may be skewed toward concluding that the dominoes with lower friction are faster.

Anyway, this was a fantastic video. Thanks again for your interest in domino toppling!

The dominoes with less surface friction (both on the dominoes and on the "floor") will fall faster because they can rotate about their COGs faster, which is a faster translation of energy than a simple "hinge" style fall.

Furthermore, I believe heavier dominoes lines fall faster because they are less affected by the sliding friction and also less affected by losses of energy such as sound and heat due to friction.

Finally, a simple pendulum should be a sufficiently consistent trigger.

Engineer here. Here are my basic ideas to make the rest more consistent:

I think that the best trigger would be something similar to pinball machine launching gauge. You put it in a still mount with two points of connection and a spring. Constant mass, constant spring tension and constant shaft lenght should guarantee consistent results.

If you want something simpler, just use a pendulum of a constant mass launched from a fiixed surface by magnetic force (to avoid any differences caused by sticky fingers etc.).

Finally, make a 20-domino buffer made of the same kind of blocks for all tests. No matter if You are testing mixed set of blocks, same kind of blocks etc. just use clear colorless dominoes as the firts 20 that are placed in pre-determined spots. That would take not only using a placing tool for these blocks, but also permanently connexting the tool to the testing surface with a hinge to ensure it is always placing blocks on the same spot.

Finally, the last thing that could affect the result, probably making a "box" around the dominows could allow to reduce any effects caused by the tester moving away from the setup and generating any air flow that could make a difference for blocks, which (as we learned) have varying mas and therefore could be affected differently by een the smalles breeze.

Hey Destin! I have an hypotheses for you if you'd like! Maybe someone's already mentioned this or you've thought about it yourself, but regarding the friction of the dominoes my guess is you've correctly identified that a higher friction between domino and ground surface makes for a faster falling train of dominoes. However, I also stipulate that there's a great deal of influence that comes from the friction between the actual dominoes, since their surfaces slides against each other when falling over. I.e a higher friction between the actual domino pieces would result in a slower moving domino train, since the falling forward motion would be hindered.

I'm not sure I've interpreted your video correctly, but if I have you were wondering about some inconsistencies in the train travelling speed between the opaque and see-through dominoes, the see-through dominoes moving faster even though they have a lower friction between themselves and the ground surface. I'm willing to bet though that the see-through dominoes also has a much lower frictional coefficient between themselves, and thus their falling motion is much smoother and less hindered than the opaque ones.

As far as I can tell the dominoes that slip fall in a fashion that results in the corner touching the next domino at a lower point relative to the table (which creates a higher top speed for the next domino) versus that non slipping ones that result in a higher hit and a slower transference of speed. And the heavier dominoes fall faster because their heavy weight leads to more inertia which creates more torque which allows it to slip easier (I assume there is a peak value to that benefit).

The slipping ones go faster bcos the point of rotation is higher which makes the radius the the tip of the domino piece shorter. No slip ones means the point of rotation of the piece is at the bottom thus larger radius.

Smaller radius results in smaller mass from the point of rotation and will go faster with equal force. Not sure if u get the picture but yea...

I would say that rather than the domino being a challenge, it's instead the precision to which you are trying to measure.

As for suggestions, switching your trigger to being a pendulum striking the first domino (and using your domino guide to index its position against the dominoes) is the first thing that comes to mind.

The next thing that comes to mind is switching to a measuring system that doesn't rely on the camera, since camera analysis can be very precise and flexible it can also take a while per test. In this type of application you would usually see either optical sensors or electrical sensors. Plastic dominoes aren't particularly interactive with various types of electrical sensors, so perhaps a simple timer between the time your striker blocks a laser and the time your last domino blocks a laser by falling? The downside here is that now you need your entire domino setup in a jig to get consistent results.
